Questions.QuestionText: He co-invented calculus, formulated the laws of motion and universal gravitation, and wrote Principia Mathematica.
This ancient Greek thinker is best known for a theorem relating the sides of a right triangle.
This theoretical physicist revolutionized our understanding of space, time, and energy with his theories of relativity.
This ancient Greek mathematician and inventor famously exclaimed “Eureka!” and legends say he lit ships on fire with a giant mirror during the Siege of Syracuse.
This British mathematician and logician is considered the father of computer science and formalized the concept of algorithms with his famous 'machine.'
This Italian mathematician introduced a sequence in which each number is the sum of the two preceding ones, now famous in nature and art.
Known as the 'Prince of Mathematicians', he introduced normal distributions, and first formalized the least squares method of estimating parameters.
Often called the 'Father of Geometry' he wrote Elements, and an efficient algorithm for finding Greatest Common Divisors.
This Swiss mathematician introduced modern notation (f(x), e, i, π) and proved the Seven Bridges of Königsberg unsolvable.
This French mathematician, known for his contributions to probability theory and hydraulics, also lent his name to a famous triangular array of numbers used in combinatorics.
